body: Having `alphaNumeric()` and `containsNonAlphaNumeric()` operate on the same character classes would be ideal. If we exclude non-latin characters how would folks validate that their inputs only had word characters/numbers?

I too would expect the method to return true for English alphabet and digits only. IIRC that's how it worked before but it was changed because people wanted it to include latin chars too for other European languages.

The current regex means:

https://github.com/cakephp/cakephp/blob/master/src/Validation/Validation.php#L147

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/625761/60197707-31a90480-9840-11e9-8f18-7870a534d7fa.png)

(Output by [RegExBuddy](https://www.regexbuddy.com/))

The Cookbook for 3.x doesn't say anything about alphanumeric:

https://www.google.ch/search?ei=Y5wTXfa1MeT4qwGwiaDYBw&q=site%3Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fbook.cakephp.org%2F3.0+%22alphanumeric%22&oq=site%3Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fbook.cakephp.org%2F3.0+%22alphanumeric%22&gs_l=psy-ab.3...1046.1853..2019...0.0..0.86.163.2......0....1..gws-wiz.bkORQoSj_8I

The Cookbook for 2.x does, however:

https://book.cakephp.org/2.0/en/models/data-validation.html

```` php
        'loginRule-1' => array(
            'rule' => 'alphaNumeric',
            'message' => 'Only alphabets and numbers allowed',
         ),
````

I think there are at least two sides to this:

1. **Our understanding** of "alpha numeric"
2. The **user expectation** of what an  "alpha numeric" validator

Wikipedia is kind of contradictive on the subject

While it explains "alphanumeric" as the following

> Alphanumeric is a combination of alphabetic and numeric characters, and is used to describe the collection of **Latin letters and Arabic digits** or a text constructed from this collection. 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphanumeric

It describes "alphabetic"/"alphabet" as

> An alphabet is a standard set of letters (basic written symbols or graphemes) that represent the phonemes (basic significant sounds) of **any spoken language** it is used to write. 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabet
Totally agree. Alphanumeric always means any number or alphabet character (A-Z + local additions per language).

I guess if somebody wants to use a restrictive validation, finds ``Validation::alphaNumeric()``, s/he might assume it is what s/she is looking for.
At the same time, if somebody wants to validate "typical" (the ones s/he is used to) letters and digits, s/he might think, too, s/he found the right one in ``Validation::alphaNumeric()`.

> [...]  local additions per language).

I think there in lies a powerful assumption in most of us. :grin:

Just some food for thought.  Python defines alpha as:

>Return true if all characters in the string are alphabetic and there is at least one character, false otherwise. Alphabetic characters are those characters defined in the Unicode character database as “Letter”, i.e., those with general category property being one of “Lm”, “Lt”, “Lu”, “Ll”, or “Lo”. Note that this is different from the “Alphabetic” property defined in the Unicode Standard.

https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str.isalpha
@othercorey That's pretty much what the current regex `'/^[\p{Ll}\p{Lm}\p{Lo}\p{Lt}\p{Lu}\p{Nd}]+$/Du'` includes along with digits.

@ADmad It seems like alphaNumeric is working and constainsNonAlphaNumeric is broken.  You could easily add asciiAlphaNumeric and constainsNonAsciiAlphaNumeric.  Just an observers opinion though.

I would suggest making a parameter instead of more copies of similar functions, but since there are existing default parameters, that would make things awkward.
@othercorey Well @chinpei215's issue is with `alphaNumeric()` as he expects `Validation::alphaNumeric('日本語')` to return `false` not `true`.

Well, unless you want to build validators based on the current locale set (which doesn't sound reasonable), seems like he just needs a new feature added to validate ascii alpha-numeric values.  

Instead of being based on locale, you could have a setting that flips whether alphaNumeric includes unicode characters by default.  If an application handles unicode user-input, it sets that to 'allow unicode', otherwise it set it to 'allow ascii only'.  I'll leave it at that in case this isn't helping.
My only concern is the disparity between `alphaNumeric()` and `containsNonAlphaNumeric()` using different sets of characters as "alpha".
@ADmad I would have the config setting affect both validators.
